You can spend your income on apples and oranges. Apples currently cost <span>&#36;</span>0.25 and oranges cost <span>&#36;</span>0.50. When your income is <span>&#36;</span>40, you buy 10 apples and 8 oranges. When your income increases to <span>&#36;</span>80, you buy 12 apples and 6 oranges

### Question 1
What type of good are apples (inferior, necessity, luxury)? Calculate the income elasticity of demand.

### Question 2
What type of good are oranges (inferior, necessity, or luxury)? Calculate the income elasticity of demand.

You can can have cereal and milk for breakfast. When milk is <span>&#36;</span>2/gallon, you consume 5 bowls of cereal per week. When milk increases to <span>&#36;</span>4/gallon, you consume 4 bowls of cereal per week.

#### Question 3
What is the relationship between these two goods?

Calculate the cross-price elasticity of demand.
